canonical_explanation.text: As responsible citizens of India, we must be aware of important social issues and do our part to make society better. The Right to Education Act (RTE, 2009) ensures that every child between 6 and 14 years gets free and compulsory education. Child labour (making children work instead of going to school) is illegal and wrong. Boys and girls are equal and deserve the same opportunities in education, sports, and careers. Gender equality means treating everyone with equal respect regardless of whether they are male or female. We also have a responsibility to protect the environment by saving water, saving electricity, planting trees, and reducing waste. People with disabilities deserve respect, support, and equal opportunities. Ramps for wheelchair users, Braille for the visually impaired, and sign language for the hearing impaired are ways to include everyone. Being a responsible citizen means following rules, helping others, respecting elders, caring for public property, and contributing to the community. Every person, including children, can make a positive difference in society.
rules: Right to Education (RTE) Act 2009: free and compulsory education for children aged 6-14
Child labour is illegal: children should study and play, not work in factories or shops
Gender equality: boys and girls have equal rights to education, sports, and opportunities
Girls should be encouraged to study, play sports, and pursue any career they choose
Environmental responsibility: save water, save electricity, plant trees, reduce waste
People with disabilities deserve respect and equal opportunities
Accessibility: ramps, Braille, sign language help people with different abilities
Responsible citizenship: follow rules, help others, respect elders, care for public property
Community service: cleaning drives, helping neighbours, participating in social activities
Every child can make a difference by being kind, responsible, and aware

questions.question_text: What does the Right to Education (RTE) Act say?

options.text: Only rich children can go to school
All children between 6 and 14 years have the right to free and compulsory education
Children can choose whether or not to go to school

questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Education (RTE) Act, passed in 2009, says that every child between 6 and 14 years must receive free and compulsory education. It is free (no fees) and compulsory (every child must attend). This right applies to all children, rich or poor, boy or girl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The RTE Act is for ALL children aged 6-14, not just rich children or boys. Education is both free and compulsory, meaning every child has the right to go to school without paying fees, and it is mandatory for them to attend.

questions.question_text: Child labour means:

options.text: Children being forced to work instead of going to school

questions.explanation_correct: Child labour means employing children in work, especially in factories, shops, or dangerous conditions, instead of allowing them to go to school. It deprives children of their childhood, education, and right to play. Child labour is illegal in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Child labour is when children are forced to work for money instead of going to school. It is different from helping at home with small chores. Working in factories, shops, or fields for long hours is child labour and is illegal.

questions.question_text: In which year was the Right to Education (RTE) Act passed?
questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Education Act was passed in 2009 and came into effect on 1 April 2010. It made education a fundamental right for every child aged 6-14. India became one of 135 countries to make education a fundamental right.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The RTE Act was passed in 2009. It ensures free and compulsory education for all children between 6 and 14 years. This was a landmark law that made education a fundamental right in India.

questions.question_text: Child labour is legal in India.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Child labour is illegal in India. The Constitution and several laws, including the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, ban the employment of children under 14 in factories and hazardous work. Children should be in school, not at work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Child labour is ILLEGAL in India. The Indian Constitution and laws like the Child Labour Act prohibit children from working in factories and hazardous conditions. Every child has the right to education, not labour.

questions.question_text: You see a 10-year-old child working at a roadside tea stall instead of going to school. Which rights are being violated?

options.text: Right to Education and Right against Exploitation

questions.explanation_correct: A 10-year-old working instead of studying violates the Right to Education (every child aged 6-14 must go to school) and the Right against Exploitation (children cannot be made to work). The child should be in school, learning and playing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When a child works instead of going to school, two Fundamental Rights are violated: the Right to Education (the child should be in school) and the Right against Exploitation (the child should not be forced to work). This is child labour and is illegal.

questions.question_text: What should you do if you see a child working in a shop during school hours?

options.text: Ignore it because it is not your problem
Tell a trusted adult, teacher, or call the Childline helpline (1098)
Ask the child to work harder

questions.explanation_correct: If you see a child working instead of going to school, you should inform a trusted adult, teacher, or call the Childline helpline (1098). Childline is a free, 24-hour helpline for children in distress. Reporting child labour helps protect children's rights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Child labour is everyone's concern. If you see it, inform a trusted adult or call Childline (1098). Ignoring it allows the problem to continue. Every child deserves to be in school, not working in a shop.

questions.question_text: The RTE Act ensures that no child can be denied admission to a school based on:

options.text: Their caste, religion, gender, or economic status

questions.explanation_correct: The RTE Act says no child can be denied admission based on caste, religion, gender, or economic status. Schools must admit all children. Private schools must also reserve 25% of seats for children from disadvantaged and economically weaker sections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Under the RTE Act, no child can be discriminated against based on caste, religion, gender, or family income. Every child has equal right to education. Schools cannot reject children because of who they are or where they come from.

questions.question_text: Gender equality means:

options.text: Boys and girls have equal rights and deserve equal opportunities
Boys and girls should not study together

questions.explanation_correct: Gender equality means that boys and girls have equal rights, equal opportunities, and equal respect. It means girls can study any subject, play any sport, and pursue any career they want, just like boys. No one should be limited because of their gender.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gender equality does not mean one gender is better. It means both boys and girls are equally capable and deserve the same opportunities. Treating anyone differently because of their gender is discrimination and goes against our Constitution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements supports gender equality?

options.text: Both boys and girls can play any sport and study any subject

questions.explanation_correct: Gender equality means that both boys and girls can play any sport, study any subject, and pursue any career. Saying that only boys can play cricket or only girls should cook is gender discrimination. Everyone should have equal opportunities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Limiting sports or subjects to one gender is wrong. Girls can be cricketers, scientists, and engineers. Boys can be chefs, nurses, and teachers. Gender equality means no restrictions based on whether you are a boy or girl.

questions.question_text: Girls should be given the same opportunities as boys to go to school and play sports.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Girls and boys are equal and deserve the same opportunities. The Indian Constitution guarantees the Right to Equality, which means no discrimination based on gender. Many Indian women have excelled in sports, science, politics, and other fields.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Girls deserve equal access to education and sports. Many Indian women have achieved great things: Kalpana Chawla (astronaut), Mary Kom (boxing), PV Sindhu (badminton), and many more. Gender should not limit anyone's opportunities.

questions.question_text: Meena wants to become an engineer when she grows up, but some people say engineering is only for boys. What should Meena do?

options.text: Believe in herself, study hard, and pursue her dream because girls can be engineers too
Wait for someone to decide her career

questions.explanation_correct: Meena should absolutely pursue her dream of becoming an engineer. Many women are successful engineers, scientists, and doctors. Gender should never stop anyone from following their dreams. India has many successful women engineers and scientists who inspire others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meena should never give up her dream. Many Indian women are engineers, doctors, scientists, and leaders. Kalpana Chawla was an astronaut, Tessy Thomas is a missile scientist. Girls can achieve anything they set their minds to.

questions.question_text: In a family, both the son and daughter want to go to school. The family can only afford one child's education. What would be the right thing to do?

options.text: Only send the son because he is a boy
Both should be sent to a government school where education is free under the RTE Act
Neither child should go to school

questions.explanation_correct: Under the RTE Act, both children have the right to free education in government schools. The family should send both children to school. Choosing one child over another based on gender is discrimination. Education is a right for every child.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both children have equal right to education. The RTE Act provides free education for all children aged 6-14 in government schools. No child should be denied education because of gender or family income.

questions.question_text: The Beti Bachao Beti Padhao programme aims to:

options.text: Save the girl child and educate her

questions.explanation_correct: 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' (Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter) is a government programme launched in 2015 to protect girl children and promote their education. It aims to change mindsets, ensure girls' survival, and encourage their education and empowerment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' means 'Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter'. It is a programme to ensure that girls are protected and educated. It fights against gender discrimination and promotes equal opportunities for girls.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a way to protect the environment?

options.text: Planting trees, saving water, and reducing waste

questions.explanation_correct: Planting trees, saving water, and reducing waste are all excellent ways to protect the environment. Trees clean the air and provide oxygen. Saving water ensures it is available for the future. Reducing waste prevents pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing garbage in rivers, burning plastic, and wasting electricity all harm the environment. The correct ways to protect it are planting trees, saving water, reducing waste, and using resources responsibly.

questions.question_text: Why should we save water?

options.text: Water is unlimited and never runs out
Clean fresh water is limited, and we need it for drinking, farming, and daily life
Only adults need to save water

questions.explanation_correct: Although Earth has a lot of water, most of it is salt water in oceans. Only about 3% is fresh water, and much of that is frozen. Clean drinking water is very limited. We need to save water for drinking, cooking, farming, and for future generations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fresh water is limited and precious. Only a small fraction of Earth's water is drinkable. Many parts of India face water shortages. Saving water is everyone's responsibility, including children. Simple actions like turning off taps help save water.

questions.question_text: Which of the following helps save electricity?

options.text: Keeping all lights on even when not needed
Switching off lights and fans when leaving a room

questions.explanation_correct: Switching off lights and fans when leaving a room is a simple but effective way to save electricity. Other ways include using LED bulbs, turning off electronic devices when not in use, and using natural light during the day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Switching off lights and fans when not needed saves electricity. Leaving lights on, running TVs unnecessarily, or keeping the fridge open all waste electricity. Saving electricity also helps the environment by reducing pollution from power plants.

questions.question_text: Planting trees helps clean the air and provides oxygen for us to breathe.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Trees absorb carbon dioxide from the air and release oxygen through photosynthesis. They also trap dust particles, provide shade, prevent soil erosion, and are home to many animals and birds. Planting trees is one of the best things we can do for the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Trees are nature's air purifiers. They absorb harmful carbon dioxide and release life-giving oxygen. Each tree can produce enough oxygen for 2-4 people. That is why planting trees is so important.

questions.question_text: Your school is organising a 'Green Day' event. Which activity would be most helpful for the environment?

options.text: A tree-planting drive in the school compound

questions.explanation_correct: A tree-planting drive is the most helpful activity for the environment. Planting trees provides oxygen, reduces pollution, prevents soil erosion, and creates habitats for birds and animals. Burning notebooks and using plastic bags harm the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tree planting is the best environmental activity. Burning things creates pollution, plastic bags are harmful, and wasting paper means cutting more trees. Schools can also organise cleaning drives, recycling projects, and water conservation activities.

questions.question_text: Rainwater harvesting means:

options.text: Collecting and storing rainwater for future use

questions.explanation_correct: Rainwater harvesting is the process of collecting and storing rainwater for future use. This can be done using rooftop collection systems, tanks, and underground storage. It helps recharge groundwater and provides water during dry periods. Many Indian states encourage rainwater harvesting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rainwater harvesting means collecting and storing rainwater, not letting it go to waste. It is an ancient practice in India that helps conserve water. In many parts of India, especially Rajasthan and Chennai, rainwater harvesting is essential.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a sustainable habit?

options.text: Using a cloth bag for shopping and a refillable water bottle
Keeping the tap running while brushing teeth

questions.explanation_correct: Using cloth bags and refillable water bottles are sustainable habits. Sustainable means using resources in a way that does not harm the environment for future generations. Cloth bags reduce plastic waste, and refillable bottles reduce plastic pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sustainable habits protect the environment for the future. Using cloth bags instead of plastic, carrying a refillable water bottle, and not wasting resources are all sustainable. Plastic pollution is a huge problem, and small changes by everyone can make a big difference.

questions.question_text: How should we treat people with disabilities?

options.text: With respect, kindness, and equal opportunities

questions.explanation_correct: People with disabilities should be treated with respect, kindness, and given equal opportunities. They are capable of achieving great things. Disabilities may be physical or mental, but everyone deserves to be included in society and treated with dignity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: People with disabilities deserve the same respect as everyone else. Ignoring, making fun of, or isolating them is wrong and hurtful. Many people with disabilities have achieved remarkable things, proving that disability does not mean inability.

questions.question_text: Braille is a system of writing that helps:
questions.explanation_correct: Braille is a writing system of raised dots that can be felt with fingertips. It was invented by Louis Braille and helps visually impaired (blind) people read and write. Each pattern of dots represents a letter, number, or punctuation mark.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Braille helps visually impaired people by using raised dots that can be felt. Sign language helps hearing-impaired people. Ramps and wheelchairs help people with mobility disabilities. Each type of aid is designed for a specific need.

questions.question_text: Sign language is used by people who have difficulty with:
questions.explanation_correct: Sign language uses hand movements, facial expressions, and body language to communicate. It is mainly used by people who are deaf (cannot hear) or have difficulty speaking. Indian Sign Language (ISL) is used in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sign language helps people who have hearing or speaking difficulties. It is a visual language using hands, facial expressions, and body movements. Learning basic sign language can help us communicate with hearing-impaired people.

questions.question_text: Why are ramps built alongside stairs in public buildings?

options.text: To help people in wheelchairs and those who cannot climb stairs
To make the building look bigger

questions.explanation_correct: Ramps are built to help people in wheelchairs, those using walkers, elderly people, and anyone who cannot climb stairs. They make buildings accessible to everyone. This is part of making our society inclusive for people with disabilities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ramps make buildings accessible for wheelchair users, elderly people, and anyone with difficulty climbing stairs. This is called accessibility. Making public places accessible to all is an important part of inclusion and equal opportunity.

questions.question_text: People with disabilities cannot achieve great things in life.
questions.explanation_correct: This is absolutely false. Many people with disabilities have achieved extraordinary things. Stephen Hawking (physicist) worked from a wheelchair. Helen Keller (author) was blind and deaf. Arunima Sinha, who lost a leg, climbed Mount Everest. Disability does not mean inability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. People with disabilities achieve amazing things every day. Arunima Sinha (amputee who climbed Everest), Sudha Chandran (dancer who lost a leg), and many Paralympians prove that disability never stops determined people.

questions.question_text: A new student in your class uses a wheelchair. How should you behave?

options.text: Stare at the wheelchair and keep your distance
Be friendly, include them in activities, and help if they need it

questions.explanation_correct: The best approach is to be friendly and welcoming. Include the student in conversations, games, and group activities. Offer help if needed, but also respect their independence. Treat them as you would treat any other friend.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Staring, ignoring, or making fun is hurtful and wrong. A wheelchair is just a tool, like glasses for eyes. The student is a person with feelings, interests, and abilities. Be friendly, be inclusive, and treat them with the same respect you give everyone.

questions.question_text: What does 'inclusion' mean?

options.text: Keeping disabled people separate from others
Making sure everyone, including people with disabilities, can participate in all activities
Only including people who are the same as you

questions.explanation_correct: Inclusion means making sure that everyone, regardless of their abilities or disabilities, can participate in all activities of society. It means removing barriers and providing support so that no one is left out. Inclusive schools, workplaces, and communities benefit everyone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inclusion is the opposite of separation. It means ensuring that everyone can participate fully in society. This requires making changes like building ramps, providing Braille books, and creating welcoming attitudes so that people with disabilities are never excluded.

questions.question_text: The Paralympics are:

options.text: International sports events for athletes with disabilities

questions.explanation_correct: The Paralympics are international sports competitions for athletes with disabilities. They are held after the Olympic Games in the same host city. Indian Paralympians like Avani Lekhara (shooting), Sumit Antil (javelin), and Devendra Jhajharia have won gold medals and made India proud.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Paralympics are global sports events for athletes with disabilities, held alongside the Olympics. Indian athletes have won many medals at the Paralympics, showing that disability does not prevent sporting excellence.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a quality of a responsible citizen?

options.text: Following rules, helping others, and respecting public property
Being selfish and thinking only about yourself

questions.explanation_correct: A responsible citizen follows rules, helps others, respects public property, pays taxes, and cares for the community. Being responsible means thinking about how your actions affect others and doing the right thing even when no one is watching.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A responsible citizen follows rules, respects others, and takes care of public property. Breaking rules, littering, and being selfish are the opposite of responsible citizenship. Good citizenship starts with small actions in daily life.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of caring for public property?

options.text: Keeping public places clean and not damaging public things

questions.explanation_correct: Caring for public property means keeping public places like parks, libraries, buses, and monuments clean and undamaged. Public property belongs to everyone, and we all have a duty to take care of it. Damaging public property is wrong and wasteful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Public property like parks, libraries, buses, and monuments belongs to all of us. We should keep them clean and not damage them. Breaking benches, writing on walls, and stealing are all examples of damaging public property.

questions.question_text: Why should we respect our elders?

options.text: Because they have more experience and wisdom, and respecting them is part of our culture
Because they will give us money
We do not need to respect elders

questions.explanation_correct: We respect elders because they have more experience and wisdom from their years of life. In Indian culture, respecting elders is an important value. We can learn from their experiences and they deserve care and gratitude for their contributions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Respecting elders is about valuing their experience and wisdom. It is an important part of Indian culture and values. Elders have contributed to building our families and society. Respecting them is a sign of good character.

questions.question_text: Following traffic rules is a responsibility of every citizen, including children.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Following traffic rules is everyone's responsibility, including children. Children should use zebra crossings, look both ways before crossing roads, wear helmets while cycling, and always follow traffic signals. Safety is everyone's duty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Traffic rules keep everyone safe. Children should use zebra crossings, wait for green signals, not play near roads, and wear helmets while cycling. Following these rules is an important part of being a responsible citizen.

questions.question_text: You see an elderly person struggling to carry heavy bags at the bus stop. What should you do?

options.text: Walk away because it is not your problem
Offer to help them carry the bags

questions.explanation_correct: Offering to help an elderly person is the kind and responsible thing to do. Helping others, especially those in need, is an important quality of a good citizen. Small acts of kindness make a big difference in the community.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Helping someone in need is a sign of good citizenship and kindness. Walking away, making fun, or stealing are all wrong behaviours. A simple offer to help can brighten someone's day and shows you are a caring and responsible person.

questions.question_text: Your colony has a lot of garbage on the streets. As a responsible citizen, what can you do?

options.text: Add more garbage to the pile
Organise a cleanliness drive with neighbours and ensure garbage goes into bins
Throw garbage into the neighbour's garden

questions.explanation_correct: Organising a cleanliness drive with neighbours is a great example of responsible citizenship. When people come together to clean their community, it makes the area better for everyone. You can also ensure dustbins are available and garbage is properly disposed of.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Responsible citizens take action to solve problems, not add to them. Organising a cleaning drive, using dustbins, and encouraging others to keep the area clean are all positive actions. Community effort can transform any area.

questions.question_text: What is community service?

options.text: Volunteering to help the community through activities like cleaning, planting trees, and helping the needy

questions.explanation_correct: Community service means volunteering your time and effort to help your community without expecting payment. Activities include cleaning public spaces, planting trees, helping at old age homes, teaching underprivileged children, and organising donation drives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Community service is about helping the community for free. It includes activities like cleaning drives, tree planting, helping the elderly, and teaching. Even children can do community service by keeping their neighbourhood clean and helping others.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the Childline helpline number in India?
questions.explanation_correct: 1098 is the Childline helpline number in India. It is a free, 24-hour helpline for any child in distress. Children can call this number if they face abuse, exploitation, child labour, or any emergency. 100 is for police, 101 for fire, and 108 for ambulance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Childline helpline number is 1098. It is free and available 24 hours. 100 is the police helpline, 101 is the fire brigade, and 108 is the ambulance. Remember 1098 for any child in need of help.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an example of environmental responsibility?

options.text: Using public transport instead of private cars
Segregating waste into wet and dry
Throwing e-waste (old phones, batteries) in the regular dustbin

questions.explanation_correct: Throwing e-waste in regular dustbins is harmful because electronic items contain toxic chemicals that can pollute soil and water. E-waste should be given to authorised e-waste recyclers. Using public transport, segregating waste, and using solar energy are all responsible actions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: E-waste (old phones, computers, batteries) should NOT go into regular dustbins because they contain harmful chemicals. They need special recycling. Using public transport, segregating waste, and solar energy are all environmentally responsible actions.

questions.question_text: The motto 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' means _____.

options.text: Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter

questions.explanation_correct: 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' translates to 'Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter'. It is a campaign to improve the welfare and education of girls in India. It aims to change attitudes, prevent gender discrimination, and ensure every girl gets an education.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Beti Bachao Beti Padhao' means 'Save the Daughter, Educate the Daughter'. 'Beti' means daughter, 'Bachao' means save, and 'Padhao' means educate. It is an important government initiative for girls' welfare and education.

questions.question_text: Which of the following shows responsible behaviour?

options.text: Taking only as much food as you can eat and composting leftover food waste
Throwing uneaten food on the ground
Taking lots of food just to show off

questions.explanation_correct: Taking only what you can eat and composting food waste shows responsibility. Wasting food is wrong because many people in India do not have enough to eat. Being mindful about food is an important part of responsible citizenship.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wasting food while millions of people go hungry is irresponsible. Taking only what you need and composting leftover food waste are responsible habits. In India, where many families struggle for food, wasting it is especially wrong.

questions.question_text: Which Indian woman was the first to go to space?
questions.explanation_correct: Kalpana Chawla was the first Indian-origin woman to go to space. She flew on the Space Shuttle Columbia in 1997 and again in 2003. Her story inspires millions of girls to dream big and pursue careers in science and technology.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kalpana Chawla was the first Indian-origin woman in space. Indira Gandhi was the first woman PM, Mother Teresa was a social worker, and Sarojini Naidu was a freedom fighter. Kalpana Chawla's story shows that girls can reach for the stars.

questions.question_text: Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle are called the 3Rs. Which of the following is an example of 'Reuse'?

options.text: Using an old jar to store spices instead of throwing it away

questions.explanation_correct: Reuse means using something again instead of throwing it away. Using an old jar to store spices, old clothes as cleaning rags, or newspapers to wrap things are all examples of reuse. This reduces waste and saves resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reuse means finding new purposes for old items instead of throwing them away. Using old jars for storage, old clothes for dusting, or old newspapers for packing are all ways to reuse. This reduces waste and helps the environment.

questions.question_text: Which Indian Paralympian won a gold medal in shooting at the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics?
questions.explanation_correct: Avani Lekhara won India's first gold medal in shooting at the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics. She uses a wheelchair due to a spinal cord injury from a car accident. Her achievement proves that disability cannot stop a determined person from reaching the top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Avani Lekhara is a Paralympic shooter who won gold for India. PV Sindhu, Mary Kom, and Saina Nehwal are Olympic athletes. Avani's story is especially inspiring because she overcame a serious injury to become a world champion.

questions.question_text: Only adults can be responsible citizens. Children are too young to contribute to society.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Children can be responsible citizens too. They can keep their surroundings clean, save water and electricity, help others, follow traffic rules, plant trees, and be kind. Even small actions by children make a big difference in society.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children are absolutely capable of being responsible citizens. They can save water, plant trees, help the elderly, keep their neighbourhood clean, and be kind to everyone. Good citizenship starts at a young age.

questions.question_text: What are the effects of child labour on children?

options.text: They miss education, face health problems, and lose their childhood

questions.explanation_correct: Child labour has severe effects: children miss out on education, face physical and mental health problems from hard work, lose their childhood of play and learning, and remain trapped in poverty. It is a cycle that must be broken through education and enforcement of laws.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Child labour is extremely harmful. It deprives children of education, damages their health, steals their childhood, and keeps them in poverty. Children who work instead of studying have fewer opportunities to improve their lives when they grow up.

questions.question_text: The Swachh Bharat Mission (Clean India Mission) aims to:

options.text: Make India clean by building toilets, managing waste, and promoting cleanliness

questions.explanation_correct: The Swachh Bharat Mission (launched in 2014) aims to make India clean. It focuses on building toilets to end open defecation, managing solid waste properly, and promoting cleanliness in cities and villages. It is inspired by Mahatma Gandhi's vision of a clean India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Swachh Bharat Mission is about making India clean. It includes building toilets, managing waste, and spreading awareness about cleanliness. It was inspired by Gandhi's dream of a clean India and is everyone's responsibility.

questions.question_text: _____ is a system of raised dots used by visually impaired people to read.
questions.explanation_correct: Braille is a system of raised dots that visually impaired people feel with their fingertips to read. It was developed by Louis Braille in the 1820s. Each character is represented by a pattern of up to six dots arranged in a cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Braille uses raised dots for reading by touch. Sign language uses hand gestures for communication. Morse code uses dots and dashes for signalling. Braille has made books, education, and information accessible to millions of visually impaired people.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions would make you a better citizen?

options.text: Standing in queue patiently, using dustbins, and being polite to everyone

questions.explanation_correct: Good citizenship involves simple daily actions: standing in queue, using dustbins, being polite, following rules, and helping others. These may seem small, but when everyone practises them, the whole society becomes better and more harmonious.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Good citizenship is about everyday actions. Standing in queues, using dustbins, being polite, and helping others are all signs of responsible behaviour. These simple habits, when practised by everyone, make our society a much better place.

questions.question_text: A girl in your class says she wants to be a pilot when she grows up. Some boys laugh and say 'girls cannot be pilots.' What is wrong with this thinking?

options.text: Nothing is wrong; boys are right
It is gender discrimination; girls can absolutely be pilots and many women are successful pilots in India
Girls should only be teachers or nurses

questions.explanation_correct: Saying girls cannot be pilots is gender discrimination. Many women are successful pilots in India, including in the Indian Air Force. Gender should never limit career choices. India has women fighter pilots, astronauts, scientists, and leaders in every field.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India has many successful women pilots, including fighter pilots in the Indian Air Force. Gender discrimination is wrong. Girls can pursue any career they want. Limiting career choices based on gender goes against the principle of equality.

questions.question_text: On World Environment Day (5 June), your school asks each student to take one action for the environment. Which would have the most lasting impact?

options.text: Planting a tree and taking care of it regularly
Buying a new plastic water bottle
Keeping all lights on at home

questions.explanation_correct: Planting a tree and taking care of it regularly has the most lasting impact. A single tree can produce oxygen for 2-4 people, absorb carbon dioxide, provide shade, prevent soil erosion, and support wildlife for decades. The key is not just planting but also caring for the tree.

questions.question_text: The phrase 'Be the change you wish to see in the world' is attributed to Mahatma Gandhi. What does it mean for students?

options.text: Wait for others to make changes
Start by changing your own behaviour: be kind, responsible, and fair, and the world around you will change

questions.explanation_correct: This quote means that instead of waiting for others to improve the world, you should start by improving yourself. If you want a clean neighbourhood, start by not littering. If you want kindness, be kind first. Students can bring change by being responsible, compassionate, and fair in their daily lives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gandhi's message is about personal responsibility. Do not wait for others to change things. Start with yourself. If every person, including every student, takes responsibility for their own actions, the whole world becomes better.
